DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Say Noriega Military Quarters Poshly Decorated
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following report was filed by members of a pool flown to Panama by the Pentagon.

Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega kept extravagant quarters on the military base shared by the United States and Panama, said U.S. soldiers Thursday who toured and helped secure the building Noriega used. The structure, known as Building 8 at Fort Amador, contained a cache of automatic weapons, a private movie theater and a poster of Adolf Hitler on the wall in Noriega's library, the soldiers said. Until the U.S. invasion early Wednesday morning, the base was a joint installation under terms of the Panama Canal Treaty. ``They have all our military manuals because we were allies,'' said Sgt. First Class Joseph Torregrossa, who looked over the Noriega quarters Thursday. Torregrossa said the DEA report discovered was a 1986-87 hardcover book that read: ``The Battle Against Drugs in Panama.'' Torregrossa said he found night-vision goggles in Noriega's offices and fully-automatic weapons, top-of-the-line items like Israeli Uzis. In all, about 250 weapons, including small Derringers, were discovered, he said. Soldiers said Noriega's quarters, in the upper two floors of the Building 8, contained plush carpeting, a fancy dining room and a movie theater. There are no windows where Noriega spent his time, one soldier said. ``This is what freaked me out,'' said another soldier identified only as Sandridge. ``Underneath his glass coffee table he had a ceramic leopard.'' Sandridge said there was a row of Noriega bats and baseball caps on a shelf and a box of Havana cigars, wrapped in paper printed with the words: ``Manuel Antonio Noriega, 4 Stars.'' Originally, reporters were to be taken to a so-called ``witch house'' that is owned or was frequented by Noriega. According to folklore, the house contains entrails and vats of blood. But after being diverted to the Army base to get clearance to view the house, reporters were told ``a boobytrap'' had been found inside and the house was not yet open to visits.
